Start by jumping and reaching for the ceiling, when you touch down, jump your feet backwards into a plank position. From here jump your feet back to your hands and perform the jump again.

Lying in a prone position with your knees bent to almost 90 degrees, either place your hands straight towards the ceiling or behind your head. From here flex your abdominal muscles and bring your elbows as close to your knees as possible.

Performed on a chair or platform, place your palms on the edge of the surface with your thumbs pointed forward With bent knees, flex your arms, gliding your back as close to the chair as possible until your arms are bent to 90 degrees. Extend your arms and return to the original position.

Standing with feet wider than shoulder width, toes pointing on a 45 degree angle, squat down until you have a 90 degree bend in your knees. Jump laterally and squat again.
Lying prone in plank position, walk alternate hands and legs in a press up motion moving forward. Aim to make contact with elbow and knee, keeping yourself as low to the ground as possible.
Either free hand or assisted, flex at the hip and bring your core constantly, particularly when lowering. Increase difficulty by extending legs.

With your hands on a bench, perform press-ups lowering yourself towards the bench until there is a 90 degree bend in your elbow. Decrease the difficulty by performing the press-ups with your knees on the ground.

Standing in a lunge position, with a 90 degree bend in your front leg, and rear knee nearly touching the ground, power off by jumping and swapping foot placement. Try to maintain your balance by keeping your hands on your hips. Alternatively walk forward without jumping to decrease difficulty.
Standing in one place, jump and tuck your knees into your chest whilst in mid air, quickly extend again to return to the start position.
Lying on your back, keep straight legs, flex at the hip until a 90 degree bend has been made. Make sure you engage your core during the entire movement and maintain constant speed and control.
In a press-up position, bring one leg under your chest, jump and swap foot position. Do this while keeping hands on the floor. This is an explosive movement which should be done with a tight core.
Similar to a standard press-up, the difference between this exercise is that your hands are directly beneath your shoulders, and your arms are pinched into your sides. This isolates your tricep more.
Lying on a 45 dgree angle, with one hand behind your head, bend at the mid section and try to make contact with your knee and elbow. This exercise, performed properly, will set your obliques on fire.
Standard pull ups, wide grip, close grip or underneath grip, whatever suits you is fine. You may also use a coloured band. Remember to drop your shoulders, and exhale on the way up.
Jump on the spot, kicking your butt with your heels. This is a quick explosive movement that is harder than it looks.

Using a suitable barbell, grip the bar close, and raise the bar to your chin, keeping elbows nice and high. This is a shoulder exercise.
Lying on your back with extended arms and legs, come up in a V Type motion and make contact with hands to feet. This takes a bit of practice and balance.

Perform press-ups with a wide grip position where your arms are wider than your shoulder width. Lower yourself to 90 degree elbow bend. This exercise can be made easier by keeping your knees on the ground. Engage your core to prevent sagging of the lower backs.
Crouch down, then jump as high as you can, performing an X while in mid air. Try to land as softly as possible.

Performing a bicep curl, but at the fully flexed position, turn your wrists over 180 degrees and lower. Then rotate the wrist at the extended position back to the standard curl position. This exercise also works your brachioradialis muscle in your forearm.

Welcome to the ABC challenge This is a full body workout designed to improve your strength, muscular endurance and anaerobic capacity. It is composed of an array of movements of different difficulties that will push your current level of fitness through the stratosphere. 
 
 The aim of the challenge is to get through as many of the exercises as possible. This may not be difficult for some of you; in this case there is a rep challenge in which you either complete 10 or 5 reps of each exercise. You also have the option to time yourself so you know if your fitness has increased as your time should decrease, providing you practice the movements enough. 
 
 Most of the exercises have options which either increase or decrease the difficulty of the exercises so you may be challenged optimally. Make sure you set a plan in your head of the exercises you will be attempting to prevent early fatigue or under stimulation. 
 
 Record your name and the letter in which you made it to, or the amount of reps completed of each letter in the space provided, there is an optional time column to complete if you wish to race against the clock. 
 
 Each single sided exercise must be performed on each side to count as one rep. These exercises are Russian twist, Lunge and Mountain Climbers. 
 
 Remember, if you are someone who shies away from a challenge because you don't like comparing yourself to others, it's an individual pursuit and the most important person you should be competing against is yourself. So give it a go, surprise yourself and take something away from this challenge. 
 
 Special thanks to all our awesome models for their great demonstrations! 
 
 If you have any questions about the challenge don't hesitate to ask our friendly Club Aqua staff as they will be more than happy to assist you. 
 
 Good Luck!
If you have an existing health condition, please consult your doctor before attempting this fitness routine.
